Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Multidisciplinary Underground Science at the Sanford Underground Research Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
Black Hills State University (BHSU) will host a 10-week Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program centered on underground science at the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF). This program will recruit 6-8 undergraduate students each year to participate in exciting underground research projects as well as professional development, social and outreach activities. Underground science offers possibilities for research across a variety of disciplines including physics, chemistry and biology. Recruitment efforts of the BHSU REU site will be especially focused on American Indian, female and community college students.

Some of the most important physics experiments of our time are currently in operation at SURF, searching for dark matter and investigating properties of the neutrino. Students will be offered the opportunity to engage in research related to these experiments by assaying materials for radiopurity measurements, using Monte Carlo simulations to investigate the effect of those materials on detectors and testing the chemical purity of noble gases. Additionally, research at SURF is being carried out in the study of life deep underground, with applications to medicine and astrobiology, in particular in the diversity of microbial environments and in the isolation of novel microbes. Complementary chemistry research will also be performed to determine the local environment in which these microbes live.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Black Hills State University (BHSU) hosted 21 students over three summers in a 10-week REU program centered on underground science at the Sanford Underground Research Facility (SURF). Students participated in exciting underground research projects as well as professional development, social and outreach activities.

Underground science offers exciting possibilities for research. Some of the most important physics experiments of our time are currently in operation at SURF, searching for dark matter and investigating properties of the neutrino. Students engaged in research related to these experiments by assaying materials for radiopurity measurements, helping to construct the LZ detector and testing the chemical purity of noble gases. Additionally, research at SURF is being carried out in the study of life deep underground, with applications to medicine and astrobiology. In particular in the diversity of microbial environments and in the isolation of novel microbes. Complementary chemistry research was also performed to determine the local environment in which these microbes live.

 The main impact of any REU program is in the importance of training future scientists. Over the last three years, 19 BHSU REU students filled out the URSSA as a post-assessment. Also, mid-course and end-of-session interviews and other data enabled project leaders to identify key aspects of REU student experiences. Important themes include:

Deep engagement with the processes and intellectual work of scientific investigation

Student work on projects engaged them deeply in the practices of science. On the URSSA questionnaire, 74% of respondents said that they had engaged in in real-world science research ?a great deal? - and the rest indicated ?a fair amount?. In the interviews, many of the students were a little surprised by the sheer workload of scientific research, but they also found the work to be interesting and engaging.

Transformed sense of self as a scientist

On the URSSA question "Confidence in my ability to contribute to science" 16/19 or 84% chose 'good gain' or "great gain". A student said that her REU experience "couldn't have been more relevant and helpful" to her future career plans to study underground microbiota. In the coming year she plans to continue at her home institution with the analyses that she began in the summer.

An American Indian student reported that she initially felt strong insecurity about her scientific ability:

"Before this summer I was kind of scared to go into the grad program. Like when I went to NIH I was really uncomfortable because I felt I wasn't as smart as everyone else, and I felt like "why was I here?" Here, everybody knows me really well and I feel comfortable. ... (Graduate school) doesn't seem as difficult as I thought and I think it would be something I could handle." As a result of her experience in this summer's REU, this student has strengthened resolve and commitment to enroll in graduate study in genetics.

Clarified career plans

On the URSSA question "Doing research clarified for me which field of study I want to pursue", 89% of the respondents chose "agree" or "strongly agree." A student who worked on the LZ dark matter detector developed a deep interest in particle physics, and now plans to apply to UC Berkeley and other schools that have particle physics research. Other students strengthened their commitments to advanced study in chemistry, biology, or physics.

Recruitment efforts was also a major focus of the BHSU REU:

  • 67% of the students were from primarily undergraduate institutions
  • 57% of the students were female
  • 38% of the students were first generation college students
  • 19% of the students were from community colleges
  • 10% of the students were from tribal colleges
